entries.author: Ingrid Lunden
entries.content: Twitter reported its Q1 earnings today, and they’re not great. On the back of 310 monthly active users, theÂ company postedÂ revenues of $595 million, with Q1 GAAP diluted earnings per share of ($0.12) and non-GAAP diluted EPS of $0.15. This is a big miss on revenues but a beat on EPS. Analysts’ expectations for non-GAAP EPS averaged out at $0.10, while the average estimateÂ for… Read More
entries.title: Twitter’s woes continue on Q1 sales of $595M, a sluggish 310M MAUs and weak guidance

entries.author: Emily Calandrelli
entries.content: SpaceX confirmed to TechCrunch that their next launch is scheduled for May 4th at 1:22 am EST with a two-hour launch window. The company is expected to couple the launch with another rocket landing attempt on a drone ship out at sea. It was less than three weeks ago that SpaceX made their first successful rocket recovery on a drone ship. Landing from the chase plane… Read More
entries.title: SpaceX’s next launch and the business of rocket recovery
FBI to keep Apple guessing on San Bernardino iPhone hack
entries.content: The FBI plansÂ not to disclose to Apple the method it used to access an iPhone belonging to the San Bernardino shooting suspect, or submit it for an internal government review, according to a Wall Street Journal report. The FBI announced in March that it had purchased a hacking tool from a third party that enabled it to access data on an iPhone used by Syed Farook. Farook and his wife are… Read More
entries.author: Kate Conger

entries.title: The restaurant OSÂ
entries.content: So you’re a techie and a foodie. You’re having dinner and your phone buzzes to let you know you can pay for the meal you’re enjoying right from an app. It’s then you realize there’s something going on in restaurant tech. Read More
entries.author: Chris Caliz

entries.title: Regulators order environmental impact study of Lyft Line and UberPOOL
entries.content: Remember when a California regulatory agency tried to shut down carpooling services like UberPOOL and Lyft Line throughout the state? Well, you can breathe a sigh of relief. Two years after its initial threats, the California Public Utilities Commission (CPUC) has decided that the services are legal and can continue to operate. However, the CPUC has ordered Uber and Lyft to provide specifics… Read More
entries.author: Kate Conger

entries.content: Today’s VR headsets are marvels of miniaturization. And, as iFixit’s teardowns show, both the Oculus Rift and HTC’s Vive are also remarkably user-friendly when it comes to repair and customization. Read More
entries.author: Devin Coldewey
entries.title: Teardown of HTC Vive highlights the headset’s differences from Oculus Rift
ToyTalk renames to PullString, repositions as authoring tool for bots
entries.author: Haje Jan Kamps
entries.content: ToyTalk, the startup that mashed together Barbie and the Internet of Things and let your kids chat away with Thomas the Tank Engine for hours on end, is cashing out on the bot craze with a slight realignment of philosophy — and a new name. The company developed a whole toolset — called PullString — to enable writers to create narratives for children’s toys. Read More

entries.author: Lucas Matney
entries.content: HTC is devoting more and more resources to virtual reality as it looks to outrun its mobile demons and catch the VR wave before everyone else. Today at a press conference in China, HTC announced that it will be devoting $100 million toÂ a new virtual reality accelerator program for developers called Vive X, VR Focus reports. Applications are live now over on HTC’s site. The accelerator… Read More
entries.title: HTC announces $100M Vive X virtual reality accelerator program
Android Wear gets a watch band standard via MODE
entries.content: Android Wear smartwatches come in many shapes and sizes — their watch bands, however, do not. Until now, of course. Read More
entries.author: Stefan Etienne

entries.title: Starbucks launched its own keyboard app so you can text emojis of unicorns drinking coffee
entries.author: Sarah Perez
entries.content: Can the latest app from Starbucks become the next Kimoji? Nah, probably not. But the company this week has released its first consumer-facing app that’s solely focused on entertainment, as opposed to its core business of selling food and drink.Â Yes, that’s right. Starbucks has its own emoji keyboard app now, so you can more easily text friends pictures of Frappuccinos, coffees,… Read More

entries.title: Tim Cook, Mark Zuckerberg and others urge Congress to fund K-12 computer science education
entries.author: Megan Rose Dickey
entries.content: Some of the biggest names in tech and corporate America, including Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg,Â Apple CEO Tim Cook, Facebook COO Sheryl SandbergÂ and Walmart CEO Doug McMillon, have teamed up with governors and educators to ask Congress to provide $250 million in federal funding to school districts in order to giveÂ every single K-12 student in the nation an opportunity to learn how to code.… Read More

entries.title: Skype for Business hits the Mac in Preview mode
entries.author: Sarah Perez
entries.content: Microsoft announced this morning the launch of Skype for Business for Mac Preview Â – the business-focused version of Skype’s communications services aimed at a commercial client base. I.T. administrators and individuals can sign up to test the new desktop software, which introduces features like Outlook integration, additional security, and calls that allow for up to 250 people… Read More

entries.title: YouTube brings a new homepage with improved recommendations to its iOS and Android apps
entries.author: Frederic Lardinois
entries.content: Next time you open the YouTube app on your iOS or Android phone, you’ll be greeted by a new homepage experience. Before, YouTube would show you a list of recommended items with small thumbnails, followed by a few more lists of recommended videos about topics you’ve recently shown interested in. Now, you’ll see a single feed of recommended videos that are all presented with… Read More

entries.title: Hover, a self-flying camera drone, lands $25M for better aerial shots
entries.content: Have you ever tried to capture close-up video of yourself or others with a traditional drone? It’s nearlyÂ impossible. To solve this problem China-based Zero Zero Robotics has raised $25M to build Hover, a small self-flying drone.Â The funding is composed mainly of a $23M Series AÂ round from IDG, and China-focusedÂ firmsÂ GSR Ventures, ZhenFund, ZUIG. While this is the first publicly… Read More
entries.author: Fitz Tepper

entries.content: Google, Uber and Lyft have joined forces with automakers Volvo and Ford, creating a coalition to influenceÂ lawmakers, regulators and the public, Automotive News reported on Tuesday. The new lobby, dubbedÂ The Self-Driving Coalition for Safer Streets, will be led by David Strickland, long-time safety watchdog who wasÂ formerly the head of theÂ U.S. National Highway Traffic Safety… Read More
entries.author: Lora Kolodny
entries.title: Google, Uber, Lyft join automakers in self-driving car lobby
TechCrunch is hiring an ambitious web developer. Could it be you?
entries.author: Nicole Wilke
entries.content: If you’re a web developer who wants to make a big impact on TechCrunch, here’s your chance! In preparation for tackling some ambitious projects, our product team has grown rapidly in recent months and we are still looking for one more. There couldn’t be a more exciting time to join us. Read More

Wattpad, a popular site where authors can share stories with readers, is announcing its broader ambitions with the launch of a new division called Wattpad Studios. The company describes Studios as a way for Wattpad to partner with the entertainment industry, and it said the new divisionÂ will operate like the multi-channel networks that work withÂ online video creators. Wattpad Studios builds… Read More
entries.author: Anthony Ha
entries.title: Wattpad sets its sights on brands, publishers and Hollywood with Wattpad Studios
Attention VCs, here are the Startup Alley companies at Disrupt NY
entries.author: Anthony Domanico
entries.content: Hey all you investors out there, we’re excited to announce the companies that will be on display in the Startup Alley at Disrupt NY, and you can check out every single one of them on our brand-new Startup Alley Hub. In addition to all sorts of great information on Startup Alley companies, the Startup Alley Hub lets you easily follow the companies you’re interested in meeting up… Read More

Last quarter,Â Twitter’s user base (excluding SMS fast-followers) actually shrankÂ — and this was a hugeÂ moment for the company. While there were whispers of peak Twitter circling for some time now, that looming theory was finally confirmed in the company’s fourth-quarter results. Twitter had gone from 307 million users to 305 million. Twitter, at one point a rocket-ship,… Read More
entries.author: Matthew Lynley
entries.title: What to expect for Twitter’s first-quarter results
Amazon cracks down on fake reviews with another lawsuit
entries.content: Amazon is continuing its efforts to crack down on fake, paid-for reviews of the products it sells on its website, by filing yet another lawsuit against those who offer glowing reviews in exchange for cash. In this latest suit, filed on Friday, the company is targeting the operators of five websites engaged in this business practice. The sites offer verified reviews for books and other… Read More
entries.author: Sarah Perez

entries.title: Modstep is now a hub for everything; learn how to use it
entries.author: Peter Kirn
entries.content:
Modstep, the step sequencer on steroids on iOS, just got a huge pile of new features. It hosts AU plug-ins (yes, iOS plug-ins). It adds per-track MIDI, for hardware and apps. It has loads of new features for clips and arranging. It is, basically, a MIDI daw with built-in instruments that’s unlike nearly anything on desktop – only it was designed from the ground-up for the iPad. In fact, it does so much that it’s a bit overwhelming. So, let’s take a birds-eye view of what’s new – and then turn to the singular educational force that s Jakob Haq ...

The post Modstep is now a hub for everything; learn how to use it appeared first on cdm createdigitalmusic.

entries.author: Peter Kirn
entries.content:
As part of a collaboration with Novation, we spoke with artists Shawn Rudiman and My Panda Shall Fly about how they’re working with Novation’s Circuit. Both artists got their hands on the updates to the Circuit hardware in advance – providing drag-and-drop sample loading and sample editing. They talk a bit about what that’s meant to them – and what they think about working with hardware in general. Track ID, from the beginning: “Dark House” by Shawn Rudiman, appropriately from his Hardware Survival Techniques EP. The video gives you some highlights, but I spoke to both artists to get more ...

The post Artists share Novation Circuit tips, with Shawn Rudiman and My Panda Shall Fly appeared first on cdm createdigitalmusic.
entries.title: Artists share Novation Circuit tips, with Shawn Rudiman and My Panda Shall Fly
